overview__hs__subheading.text: Securely and easily add location data to applications

overview__wal__feature_1__label.text: Access cost-effective, high-quality geospatial data from trusted data providers.

overview__wal__feature_2__label.text: Protect user privacy, shield your sensitive information, and reduce your application's security risks.

overview__wal__feature_3__label.text: Quickly deploy and accelerate application development with seamless integrations with AWS services.

overview__wal__feature_4__label.text: Easily integrate geospatial data into an applications for different use cases or geographies with data from multiple providers.

overview__routes__subheading.text: Find and plan optimized routes with estimated time and distance

overview__geofences__subheading.text: Define virtual boundaries. Detect entry or exit events

overview__etlb__label_1.text: Get started with Amazon Location today.

overview__etlb__label_2.text: Three months free with the AWS Free Tier.

product__subheading.text: Discover Amazon Location tools you need to build location-based services and applications that can be used to find nearby places, get directions, and display real-time traffic updates.

product__places__product_1__info.text: Geocodes free-form text, such as an address, name, city, or region to allow you to search for Places or points of interest.

product__places__product_2__info.text: Reverse geocodes a given coordinate and returns a legible address.

product__places__product_3__info.text: Generates suggestions for addresses and points of interest based on partial or misspelled free-form text.

product__places__product_4__info.text: Finds details of a place by its unique PlaceId. A PlaceId is returned by other search operations.

product__maps__product_1__info.text: Retrieves glyphs used to display labels on a map. Glyphs is a binary file containing encoded Unicode characters.

product__maps__product_2__info.text: Retrieves glyphs used to display labels on a map. Glyphs is a binary file containing encoded Unicode characters.

product__maps__product_3__info.text: Retrieves the map style descriptor from a map resource. Map style defines color and other style information for the data to define how it will look when rendered.

product__maps__product_4__info.text: Retrieves a vector data tile. A Map tile format stores map data using vector shapes and used by a map renderer client to render a map.

product__routes__product_1__info.text: Calculates routes between an origin and a destination, with up to 23 waypoints along the route, for different modes of transportation, avoidances, and traffic conditions.

product__routes__product_2__info.text: Generates matrix from a set of departure positions to a set of destination positions. Useful as inputs into route planning or optimization software.

product__geofences__product_1__info.text: Create, Read, Update and Delete a Geofence Collection. A geofence Collection contains zero or more geofences.

product__geofences__product_2__info.text: Create, Read, Update and Delete a Geofence. Geofence is polygon geometry that defines a virtual boundary on a map.

product__geofences__product_3__info.text: Stores or Deletes a batch of geofences from a geofence collection.

product__geofences__product_4__info.text: Evaluates device positions against the geofence geometries from a given geofence collection. Also, sends notifications when it determines if the device has entered or exited a geofenced area.

product__trackers__product_1__info.text: Create, Read, Update and Delete a Tracker. Trackers help retrieve current and historical location of devices.

product__trackers__product_2__info.text: Association or disassociate a tracker resource from a geofence collection.

product__trackers__product_3__info.text: Retrieves most recent position of device(s)

product__trackers__product_4__info.text: Retrieves the device(s) position history within a specified range of time.

help__subheading.text: Detailed instructions for creating, deleting and troubleshooting the Demo app's stack.

help__item_1__desc.text: Running a CloudFormation template via your own AWS account to configure a stack which creates all the necessary resources.

help__item_1__content_1.text: Open sidebar on demo page and click on [click here] link to get redirected to AWS console.

help__item_1__content_2.text: Once redirected, if your AWS isn't logged in, you'll be asked to login.

help__item_1__content_3.text: After login you'll be taken to CloudFormation create stack step and you'd notice that Amazon S3 URL field is prefilled. Click on Next.

help__item_1__content_4.text: On the next step enter any email address in CognitoUserEmail field, you'll be sent a temporary password on this email, which will be later used to login into the applicatoin using Amazon Hosted UI. Click on Next.

help__item_1__content_5.text: Do not modify any config on the next couple of steps and simply proceed by clicking Next, until you are presented with the Submit button, here accept the acknowledgement and press Submit.

help__item_1__content_6.text: You'll see that the stack is now being created, depending on you internet speed this step can take from 5 to 10 minutes. Once the stack creation is completed, go to Outputs tab.

help__item_1__content_7.text: Copy and paste all the values into the form. Make sure all values are copied correctly to ensure a successful connection. Click on Connect.

help__item_1__content_8.text: If you encounter any error, make sure that all the values copied from step 6 are correct and try again, once succeeded, you'd notice a success state.

help__item_1__content_9.text: You can now either continue to use Maps, Places and Routes funtionality or sign in to use Geofence and Tracking functionality. Use the email you entered in step 4 and enter the temporary password that you received on that email.

help__item_1__content_10.text: You'd be asked to updated your temporary password if you are using the credentials for the first time.

help__item_1__content_11.text: After you have successfully logged in, you'd notice in the sidebar that Geofence and Tracking functionality is now unlocked/enabled.

help__item_2__content_1.text: Make sure you have signed out of the application.

help__item_2__content_2.text: After signing out, make sure to Disconnect AWS Account.

help__item_2__content_3.text: Once disconnected, go to AWS Console and search for CloudFormation.

help__item_2__content_5.text: After selecting the above mentioned stack, Click on Delete.

help__item_3__desc.text: Ways to resolve possible issues that could arise while deleting a stack. Such as corruption of stack.

help__item_3__content_1.text: Sometimes the stack might fail to be deleted successfully.

help__item_3__content_2.text: In that case, search for IoT Core in the search box and open it.

help__item_3__content_3.text: In the left sidebar, select Policies under Security and select AmazonLocationIotPolicy and click on Delete.

help__item_3__content_5.text: Go back to CloudFormation service, select amazon-location-resource-setup stack and click on Delete.

help__item_3__content_6.text: A confirmation popup would appear asking if you'd like to retain resources, without checking anything, click on Delete stack, after a few minutes the stack should be deleted successfully.

sa__ad__30.text: you can use the version history to work this out, if this matters to you. Instead, we intend that those contributors who later modified the file, agree to release their changes under the Apache license. The conventional way of signifying this is to duplicate the Apache headers at the top of each file each time a change is made by a different author, but this would quickly become impractical.

sa__ad__31.text: Where the copyright header says something like:

sa__ad__32.text: // Copyright 2013 Johns Hopkins University (author: Daniel Povey)

sa__ad__33.text: it is because the individual who wrote the code was at that institution as an employee, so the copyright is owned by the university (and we will have checked that the contributions were in accordance with the open-source policies of the institutions concerned, including getting them vetted individually where necessary). From a legal point of view the copyright ownership is that of the institution concerned, and the (author: xxx) in parentheses is just informational, to identify the actual person who wrote the code, and is not intended to have any legal implications.  In some cases, however, particularly early on, we just wrote the name of the university or company concerned, without the actual author's name in parentheses. If you see something like

sa__ad__35.text: it does not imply that Arnab was working for Microsoft, it is because someone else contributed to the file while working at Microsoft (this would be Daniel Povey, in fact, who was working at Microsoft Research at the outset of the project).

sa__ad__36.text: The list of authors of each file is in an essentially arbitrary order, but is often chronological if they contributed in different years.

sa__ad__155.text: While Xiph.Org, Broadcom, and Microsoft filed IPR disclosures giving royalty-free licenses to their patents used in Opus, four companies that did not directly participate in the development of Opus, Qualcomm, Huawei, France Telecom, and Ericsson, filed IPR disclosures with potentially royalty-bearing terms. The IETF allows anyone (and their dog) to file an IPR disclosures if they think that their patents “covers or may ultimately cover” a standard. In fact, for any organization who can be said to have contributed in any (very loosely defined) way, these IPR statements are not just allowed, but required. It is thus safer for organisations to declare as much as they can. As an example, one can find similar non-free Qualcomm IPR statements on both SIP and SDP. To our advantage, however, the IETF IPR disclosure policies require companies to provide the actual patent numbers. This allows anyone to verify these claims for themselves, which is definitely a good thing.

sa__ad__156.text: When it comes to patents, it is difficult to say much without making lawyers nervous. However, we can say something quite direct: external counsel Dergosits & Noah has advised us that Opus can be implemented without the need to license the patents disclosed by Qualcomm, Huawei, France Telecom, or Ericsson. We can also say that Mozilla is confident enough in Opus to ship it to hundreds of millions of Firefox users. Similarly, Cisco and Google are also supporting Opus in some products. More companies are expected to do the same soon.

sa__ad__157.text: Mozilla invested significant legal resources into avoiding known patent thickets when designing Opus. Whenever possible, we used processes and methods that have been long known in the field and which are considered patent-free. In addition, we filed numerous patent applications on the new things we invented to help defend the Opus community. As a result, Opus is available on a royalty-free basis and can be deployed by anyone, including other open-source projects. Everyone knows this is an incredibly challenging legal environment to operate in, but we think we’ve succeeded.

caam__desc.text: Connect your AWS account to enable Geofences and Trackers. This will ensure your tracking and geofencing data is only stored in your account. After you log in, all features of the Demo App will run using resources you deploy in your AWS account. Log out if you wish to continue running the Demo App using resources in AWS’s demo app account.

caam__step_1__title.text: to run a CloudFormation template to securely create required resources.

caam__step_1__desc.text: You can delete these resources through the stack deletion option or ‘Manage resources’ pages in the menu on the left. Please note, Grab resources can only be created in ap-southeast-1 region.

caam__step_2__title.text: Connect the demo app with the recently created AWS resources by copying in input fields.

caam__step_2__desc.text: From your CloudFormation output section copy the corresponding named values as reflected in the right section form (IdentityPoolId etc).

caam__step_3__title.text: Log in using the generated user credentials.

caam__step_3__desc.text: Now you should be able to use the tracking and geofencing features using data stored in your account.

caam__post_connect__title.text: Your AWS account is now connected.

caam__post_connect__desc.text: Please Sign in to access Tracking and Geofence features or continue to use other features as unauthenticated user.

grab_cm__desc.text:
Grab provides Maps, Routes and Place search in Malaysia, Philippines, Thailand, Singapore, Vietnam, Indonesia, Myanmar, and Cambodia.
While car and motorcycle routes are available across the above countries, the bicycle and walking routes are supported in only key cities such as Singapore, Jakarta, Manila, Klang Valley, Bangkok, Ho Chi Minh City, and Hanoi.

samples__js-map-style-change__bodyText.text: This sample app shows you how to switch between different map styles. It uses Amazon Location Service's Maps as the base map provider and MapLibre GL JS as the map rendering library.

samples__js-map-style-change__configure.text: Open index.html and use the CloudFormation stack outputs to enter your Cognito Identity Pool ID.

samples__js-map-style-change__cleanUp.text: If you would like to remove all of the resources created in this walkthrough, delete the CloudFormation stack called `map-style-change`.

samples__react-map-with-amplify__title.text: Display a web map using React and AWS Amplify

samples__react-map-with-amplify__bodyTex.text: This example demonstrates how to display a web map using React and AWS Amplify UI.

samples__react-map-with-amplify__configu.text:
Copy `.env.example` to `.env` and populate environment variables with the CloudFormation stack
outputs.

samples__react-map-with-amplify__run.text:
Run `npm start` to start a local web server on [`localhost:3000`](http://localhost:3000/) with this
example and open it in a browser.

samples__react-map-with-amplify__cleanUp.text:
To remove all of the resources created in this walkthrough, delete the CloudFormation stack named
`react-map-with-amplify`.
